Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on how the Hebbian, or spike timing-dependent plasticity (STDP), influences the activity of networks of neurons in the hippocampus to mediate behavioral learning. Using a combination of computational modeling and behavioral electrophysiology, Mayank Mehta and his collaborators have shown that there are large, associative, and anticipatory changes in the activity of hippocampal place-selective neurons with experience, termed place cell plasticity. The experimental measurements of place cell plasticity are consistent with Dr. Mehtas and others computational theories of temporal sequence learning via STDP. Thus, place cell plasticity provides an assay for understanding network mechanisms of learning.

In this project, Dr. Mehta will develop biophysical computational theories of learning in networks of neurons via STDP, improving on existing simplified models. The predictions of these computational models will be tested experimentally using behavioral electrophysiology. These experiments will help to isolate the contribution of STDP from other, non-specific mechanisms, to place cell plasticity and learning. This combination of theoretical and experimental approaches will enhance our understanding of how synaptic plasticity modifies the activity of complex networks of neurons to generate behavioral learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A brain region called the hippocampus is crucial for spatial learning and navigation. The goal of this project was to understand how neurons in hippocampus encode space and learn. To do this we developed biophysical models of learning in neuronal networks and measured neural activity in behaving rodents. Our work generated a simplified mathematical model of how complex biophysical parameters influence synaptic plasticity and predicted a novel role for neural rhythms in learning. Our experimental data provided preliminary support for our model by showing that neural rhythms crucial for learning are indeed strongly enhanced when subjects run in space. This suggests that behavior enhances neural rhythms, which then enhance neuronal learning of spatial maps. These results further showed that neurons are using these rhythms to not only facilitate learning but encode information. In particular, just as a radio can use amplitude modulated (AM) or frequency modulated (FM) code for transmitting signal, neurons use AM and FM modulation of neural signals to transmit information about running speed, a surprising and novel finding. In subsequent work we showed that neurons are can autonomously generate rhythms when subjects are immobile or asleep and these rhythms play a crucial role in learning and memory during sleep.
